nexttext:
where $H_{\rm TLS}$ is the TLS Hamiltonian, $H_{\rm qp}$ are the free quasiparticle Hamiltonians of the left and right lead and $H_C$ is the coupling between both subsystems.
Since the microscopic nature of TLS remains unclear, we use the phenomenological TLS standard model for $H_{\rm TLS}$ of Ref.~\cite{PhilipsSTM}. It describes the TLS as an effective charged particle trapped in a double well potential with asymmetry $\epsilon$ between the two potential minima and tunneling amplitude $\Delta_0$,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H=H_{\rm TLS}+H_{\rm qp}+H_{C}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>qp</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
In the TLS eigenbasis the Hamiltonian reduces to $H_{\rm TLS} = \frac{1}{2}E_{\rm TLS}\,\tilde\sigma_z$
with  $E_{\rm TLS}=\sqrt{\Delta_0^2+\epsilon^2}$. Electrons in nearby leads couple to the TLS' electric dipole moment and induce an interaction that is well established in the context oft metallic glasses \cite{BlackInteraction}:
prevtext:
where $H_{\rm TLS}$ is the TLS Hamiltonian, $H_{\rm qp}$ are the free quasiparticle Hamiltonians of the left and right lead and $H_C$ is the coupling between both subsystems.
Since the microscopic nature of TLS remains unclear, we use the phenomenological TLS standard model for $H_{\rm TLS}$ of Ref.~\cite{PhilipsSTM}. It describes the TLS as an effective charged particle trapped in a double well potential with asymmetry $\epsilon$ between the two potential minima and tunneling amplitude $\Delta_0$,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{\rm TLS}=\frac{\epsilon}{2}\sigma_{z}+\frac{\Delta_{0}}{2}\sigma_{x}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mi>ϵ</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>z</mi></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Here, $g_{kk'}$ is the coupling strength between electrons and the TLS dipole and $c_k$ is an electron annihilation operator with multi-index $k=\{\vec k,\sigma,\alpha\}$ that includes electron momentum $\vec k$, spin $\sigma$, and the index $\alpha=l,r$ of the lead (\emph{left} or \emph{right}), where the electron resides.
In general we can distinguish two processes: Electrons that tunnel through the junction ($\alpha\neq\alpha'$) while interacting with the TLS and electrons, that scatter back into their original lead ($\alpha=\alpha'$).
Because of the exponentially decaying electron wave function inside the junction and the localized character of the TLS wave function, the interaction rapidly decreases for TLS  away from the junction edges.
We expect that for most TLS scattering electrons are the main source of TLS decoherence, while the influence of tunneling electrons is insignificant. This is quite different for the decoherence of a qubit, where only tunneling electrons couple to the qubit and induce decoherence.

Furthermore, electrons that contribute to TLS decoherence have energies close to the Fermi energy with momentum $|\vec k|=k_F$. 
Hence, we take the direction average and introduce the direction-averaged coupling constant $g_{\alpha\alpha'}^2\equiv\langle g_{kk'}^2\rangle$. Since $|\vec k|\approx k_F$ the averaged coupling constant does not depend on energy.


The free particles in the leads are  Bogoliubov quasiparticles with mixed electron- and hole-like nature and creation operators $a_{k}^{\dagger}$  and Hamiltonian
prevtext:
In the TLS eigenbasis the Hamiltonian reduces to $H_{\rm TLS} = \frac{1}{2}E_{\rm TLS}\,\tilde\sigma_z$
with  $E_{\rm TLS}=\sqrt{\Delta_0^2+\epsilon^2}$. Electrons in nearby leads couple to the TLS' electric dipole moment and induce an interaction that is well established in the context oft metallic glasses \cite{BlackInteraction}:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{C}=\sigma_{z}\hat{V}=\sigma_{z}\sum_{kk^{\prime}}\left(g_{kk^{\prime}}c_{k}%
^{\dagger}c_{k^{\prime}}+h.c.\right)." display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>z</mi></msub><mover accent="true"><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>z</mi></msub><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub><msubsup><mi>c</mi><mi>k</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><msub><mi>c</mi><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Their energy is $E_k=\sqrt{\xi_k^2+\Delta_{\rm bcs}^2}$ with $\xi_k$ being the electron energy in the normal state. Rewriting the coupling Eq. \eqref{eq:Coupling} in terms of quasiparticle operators we find

Here, $g_{kk'}$ is the coupling strength between electrons and the TLS dipole and $c_k$ is an electron annihilation operator with multi-index $k=\{\vec k,\sigma,\alpha\}$ that includes electron momentum $\vec k$, spin $\sigma$, and the index $\alpha=l,r$ of the lead (\emph{left} or \emph{right}), where the electron resides.
In general we can distinguish two processes: Electrons that tunnel through the junction ($\alpha\neq\alpha'$) while interacting with the TLS and electrons, that scatter back into their original lead ($\alpha=\alpha'$).
Because of the exponentially decaying electron wave function inside the junction and the localized character of the TLS wave function, the interaction rapidly decreases for TLS  away from the junction edges.
We expect that for most TLS scattering electrons are the main source of TLS decoherence, while the influence of tunneling electrons is insignificant. This is quite different for the decoherence of a qubit, where only tunneling electrons couple to the qubit and induce decoherence.

Furthermore, electrons that contribute to TLS decoherence have energies close to the Fermi energy with momentum $|\vec k|=k_F$. 
Hence, we take the direction average and introduce the direction-averaged coupling constant $g_{\alpha\alpha'}^2\equiv\langle g_{kk'}^2\rangle$. Since $|\vec k|\approx k_F$ the averaged coupling constant does not depend on energy.


The free particles in the leads are  Bogoliubov quasiparticles with mixed electron- and hole-like nature and creation operators $a_{k}^{\dagger}$  and Hamiltonian
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{\rm qp}=\sum_{k}E_{k}a_{k}^{\dagger}a_{k}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>qp</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>k</mi></munder><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>a</mi><mi>k</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with coherence factors $u_k^2=1-v_k^2=\frac12 (1+\xi_k/E_k)$. For tunneling quasiparticles $\varphi$ is the superconducting phase difference across the junction. The phase difference $\varphi$ vanishes for scattering quasiparticles.

An important quantity in the context of decoherence is the noise spectral density
prevtext: Their energy is $E_k=\sqrt{\xi_k^2+\Delta_{\rm bcs}^2}$ with $\xi_k$ being the electron energy in the normal state. Rewriting the coupling Eq. \eqref{eq:Coupling} in terms of quasiparticle operators we find
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{V}=\sum_{kk^{\prime}}g_{\alpha\alpha^{\prime}}\left(e^{i\varphi/2}u_{k}u_%
{k^{\prime}}-e^{-i\varphi/2}v_{k}v_{k^{\prime}}\right)a_{k}^{\dagger}a_{k^{%
\prime}}+h.c." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mrow><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>φ</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>φ</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>a</mi><mi>k</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where the average is over the quasiparticle states. With Eq. \eqref{eq:V} we find
\begin{eqnarray}\notag
 S_V(\omega) = & 4N_0^2g_{\alpha\alpha'}^2\int_{\Delta_{\rm bcs}}^\infty\int_{\Delta_{\rm bcs}}^\infty dEdE'\,\rho(E)\rho(E')
 \\ \notag
 & \times \left(1- \frac{\Delta_{\rm BCS}^2}{EE'}\cos\varphi\right)
 \\ \notag
& \times \{f_\alpha(E)[1-f_{\alpha'}(E')]\delta(E-E'+\omega)
  \\ 
&+f_{\alpha'}(E')[1-f_\alpha(E)]\delta(E'-E+\omega)\} \label{eq:spectralDensity}
\end{eqnarray}
with the density of states at the Fermi energy of the normal state $N_0$, the BCS density of states $\rho(E)=E/\sqrt{E^2-\Delta_{\rm BCS}^2}$ and the quasiparticle distribution function $f(E_k)=\langle a_k^\dagger a_k^{\phantom\dagger}\rangle$. 
We assume that the quasiparticles can be described with equilibrium BCS gap and density of states, but with a non-equilibrium distribution function $f(E_k)$. 
Due to the square root singularity of the BCS density of states, the noise spectral density is log-divergent at low frequencies for \emph{tunneling} quasiparticles, e.g. $\varphi\neq0$. \emph{Scattering} quasiparticles, e.g. $\varphi=0$ have a finite spectral density at low frequencies.





\section{TLS Decoherence}
The time evolution of the TLS in the presence of the quasiparticle reservoirs is best described with the help of the reduced density matrix
prevtext:
with coherence factors $u_k^2=1-v_k^2=\frac12 (1+\xi_k/E_k)$. For tunneling quasiparticles $\varphi$ is the superconducting phase difference across the junction. The phase difference $\varphi$ vanishes for scattering quasiparticles.

An important quantity in the context of decoherence is the noise spectral density
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S_{V}(\omega)=\int\frac{dt}{2\pi}\langle\hat{V}(t)\hat{V}(0)\rangle e^{i\omega
t}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

where the average is over the quasiparticle states. With Eq. \eqref{eq:V} we find
\begin{eqnarray}\notag
 S_V(\omega) = & 4N_0^2g_{\alpha\alpha'}^2\int_{\Delta_{\rm bcs}}^\infty\int_{\Delta_{\rm bcs}}^\infty dEdE'\,\rho(E)\rho(E')
 \\ \notag
 & \times \left(1- \frac{\Delta_{\rm BCS}^2}{EE'}\cos\varphi\right)
 \\ \notag
& \times \{f_\alpha(E)[1-f_{\alpha'}(E')]\delta(E-E'+\omega)
  \\ 
&+f_{\alpha'}(E')[1-f_\alpha(E)]\delta(E'-E+\omega)\} \label{eq:spectralDensity}
\end{eqnarray}
with the density of states at the Fermi energy of the normal state $N_0$, the BCS density of states $\rho(E)=E/\sqrt{E^2-\Delta_{\rm BCS}^2}$ and the quasiparticle distribution function $f(E_k)=\langle a_k^\dagger a_k^{\phantom\dagger}\rangle$. 
We assume that the quasiparticles can be described with equilibrium BCS gap and density of states, but with a non-equilibrium distribution function $f(E_k)$. 
Due to the square root singularity of the BCS density of states, the noise spectral density is log-divergent at low frequencies for \emph{tunneling} quasiparticles, e.g. $\varphi\neq0$. \emph{Scattering} quasiparticles, e.g. $\varphi=0$ have a finite spectral density at low frequencies.





\section{TLS Decoherence}
The time evolution of the TLS in the presence of the quasiparticle reservoirs is best described with the help of the reduced density matrix

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\rho(t)={\operatorname{Tr}}\left[\varrho(t)\right]_{\rm qp}\equiv\begin{%

U_{I}^{\dagger}(t)\right]e^{iH_{\rm TLS}t}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>Tr</mo><mi>qp</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>I</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϱ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>U</mi><mi>I</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
and $H_{C,I}(t')$ the coupling in the interaction picture. It is assumed that the initial density matrix,
$\varrho(t_0)\equiv\rho(t_0)\rho_{\rm qp}(t_0)$,  factorizes into a quasiparticle and TLS component and that initial correlations are irrelevant on experimental time scales.
We can distinguish two effects due to the quasiparticles: Decay and decoherence. The former describes exponential decay of diagonal elements of the TLS density matrix to their stationary state values, while the latter concerns the decay of off-diagonal elements. 

Transforming the coupling \eqref{eq:Coupling} into the TLS energy basis we find two contributions $\sigma_z\to \epsilon/E_{\rm TLS}\, \tilde\sigma_z+\Delta_0/E_{\rm TLS}\, \tilde\sigma_x$. 
The off-diagonal term $\sim \tilde\sigma_x$ induces transitions and is responsible for the decay rate $\Gamma_1$. It can be calculated in first-order perturbation theory \cite{PhysRevB.72.134519},
prevtext: where $U_I(t,t_0)$ is the time evolution operator

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="U_{I}(t,t_{0})=\text{Texp}\left[-i\int_{t_{0}}^{t}dt^{\prime}\,H_{C,I}(t^{%
\prime})\right]," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>I</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mtext>Texp</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mi>t</mi></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: The diagonal coupling $\sim\tilde\sigma_z$ generates pure dephasing, determined by the low-energy part of the spectral density. Due to the strong energy dependence in this energy range pure dephasing does not lead to a simple exponential decay law. Rather the off-diagonal elements of the density matrix take the form

We can distinguish two effects due to the quasiparticles: Decay and decoherence. The former describes exponential decay of diagonal elements of the TLS density matrix to their stationary state values, while the latter concerns the decay of off-diagonal elements. 

Transforming the coupling \eqref{eq:Coupling} into the TLS energy basis we find two contributions $\sigma_z\to \epsilon/E_{\rm TLS}\, \tilde\sigma_z+\Delta_0/E_{\rm TLS}\, \tilde\sigma_x$. 
The off-diagonal term $\sim \tilde\sigma_x$ induces transitions and is responsible for the decay rate $\Gamma_1$. It can be calculated in first-order perturbation theory \cite{PhysRevB.72.134519},

}(-E_{\rm TLS})\right]." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mi>TLS</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

where $h(t)$ describes the deviations from the simple exponential decay. It reduces to a linear time-dependence  only for flat spectral densities and long times.

The contour time-ordering operator $T_c$ orders along a contour from $t_0$ to $t$ and back again. To further evaluate that expression we expand the exponential and introduce an additional approximation \cite{Zanker15}:

This form of the density matrix follows from Eq. \eqref{eq:Dyson} and the fact that the TLS--quasiparticle coupling is diagonal in TLS space for pure dephasing. nexttext: With this approximation the quasiparticles behave similar to a Gaussian noise source \cite{PhysRevB.72.134519} and we find
prevtext:
The contour time-ordering operator $T_c$ orders along a contour from $t_0$ to $t$ and back again. To further evaluate that expression we expand the exponential and introduce an additional approximation \cite{Zanker15}: 
We assume that we can split averages over $V_i$ operators in the form
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle V(t_{1})V(t_{2})\dots V(t_{n})\rangle=\prod_{\rm perm}\langle V(t_{i})%
V(t_{j})\rangle\cdots\langle V(t_{k})V(t_{l})\rangle" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mi>perm</mi></munder><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>l</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
This specific form for pure dephasing is well established in the context of magnetic resonance  or qubit experiments in a Ramsey protocol. 

The weighting function $g(\omega t) = \sin^2(\omega t/2)/(\omega t/2)^2$ has a pronounced peak for zero energy and decreases rapidly for larger $\omega$. Therefore, the Ramsey-type experiments are sensitive to the spectral density at low energies. 

Within the Gaussian approximation we can extend our analysis to more sophisticated measurement protocols, such as spin echo  or  more complicated refocusing techniques that suppress low-frequency noise contributions.


The dephasing function $h(t)$ for those protocols looks very much like the Ramsey function but with different filter functions depending on the particular pulse protocol \cite{nphys1994}
prevtext: With this approximation the quasiparticles behave similar to a Gaussian noise source \cite{PhysRevB.72.134519} and we find
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="h_{R}(t)=t^{2}\int d\omega\,S_{qp}(\omega)\,\frac{\sin^{2}\left(\omega t/2%
\right)}{\left(\omega t/2\right)^{2}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>R</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>ω</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>sin</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: E.g. for spin echo, which is the 'first order' improvement to the Ramsey experiment, the filter function is
prevtext:
This specific form for pure dephasing is well established in the context of magnetic resonance  or qubit experiments in a Ramsey protocol. 

The weighting function $g(\omega t) = \sin^2(\omega t/2)/(\omega t/2)^2$ has a pronounced peak for zero energy and decreases rapidly for larger $\omega$. Therefore, the Ramsey-type experiments are sensitive to the spectral density at low energies. 

Within the Gaussian approximation we can extend our analysis to more sophisticated measurement protocols, such as spin echo  or  more complicated refocusing techniques that suppress low-frequency noise contributions.


The dephasing function $h(t)$ for those protocols looks very much like the Ramsey function but with different filter functions depending on the particular pulse protocol \cite{nphys1994}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="h(t)=t^{2}\int d\omega\,S_{qp}(\omega)\,g(\omega t)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>ω</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with a maximum slightly shifted to higher frequencies. For typical experimental times in the range of microseconds the filter function measures the spectral density at energy equivalents of several MHz.


\section{Non--Equilibrium Quasiparticles}\label{sec:Decoherence}
Based on the dephasing functions  \eqref{eq:GeneralDephasing} and \eqref{eq:Ramsey} as well as the decay rate \eqref{eq:gamma1} we are ready to analyze the dephasing process due to quasiparticles. The spectral density \eqref{eq:spectralDensity} depends on the quasiparticle distribution function.
Several experiments provide evidence that, even at low temperatures where quasiparticles should be exponentially suppressed with the BCS gap, finite densities of quasiparticles remain, estimated to be $n_{qp}\sim 10^{-6} \cdot\Delta_{\rm BCS}N_0$ \cite{PhysRevLett.103.097002}. 
Similar to the treatment of non-equilibrium quasiparticles for qubit decoherence, e.g. in Ref.~\cite{PhysRevB.86.184514}, we assume that both, the BCS gap and the density of states are not changed, but the distribution function is of a non-equilibrium form.
Although the exact form depends on experimental details most of the non-equilibrium quasiparticles have energies close to the superconducting gap because of scattering with phonons and among each other. 
We therefore assume that the distribution function has a width $\delta$ above the gap, which for a Fermi distribution is determined by temperature, $\delta_{\rm eq}\sim k_BT$, but here it is treated as a parameter. In the following we derive analytical forms for the different rates in the experimental relevant long-time limit $t\gg \delta^{-1}$.


\subsection{Decay}
The relevant energy scale for TLS decay is the TLS energy splitting $E_{\rm TLS}$ as evident from Eq. \eqref{eq:gamma1}. 
The TLS which can be probed by a qubit have energy splittings close to that of the qubit and thus fulfill $E_{\rm TLS}\gg \delta$. In order to evaluate the spectral density in this limit we introduce the normalized quasiparticle density
prevtext: E.g. for spin echo, which is the 'first order' improvement to the Ramsey experiment, the filter function is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="g_{e}(\omega t)=\sin^{4}\left(\omega t/4\right)/\left(\omega t/4\right)^{2}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>sin</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: For typical TLS energies $\Delta_{\rm BCS}\gg E_{\rm TLS}\gg\delta$ we can apply the 'low-energy' approximation to evaluate the spectral density at the TLS energy \cite{PhysRevB.86.184514, PhysRevB.85.144503}. In this limit all quasiparticle energies in Eq. \eqref{eq:spectralDensity} can be set to $\Delta_{\rm BCS}$. The only exception is the quasiparticle energy in the divergent BCS density of states together with the corresponding distribution function $f(E)$. They enter in the quasiparticle density \eqref{eq:xqp} and the spectral density, describing the decay, reads as
prevtext:
with a maximum slightly shifted to higher frequencies. For typical experimental times in the range of microseconds the filter function measures the spectral density at energy equivalents of several MHz.


\section{Non--Equilibrium Quasiparticles}\label{sec:Decoherence}
Based on the dephasing functions  \eqref{eq:GeneralDephasing} and \eqref{eq:Ramsey} as well as the decay rate \eqref{eq:gamma1} we are ready to analyze the dephasing process due to quasiparticles. The spectral density \eqref{eq:spectralDensity} depends on the quasiparticle distribution function.
Several experiments provide evidence that, even at low temperatures where quasiparticles should be exponentially suppressed with the BCS gap, finite densities of quasiparticles remain, estimated to be $n_{qp}\sim 10^{-6} \cdot\Delta_{\rm BCS}N_0$ \cite{PhysRevLett.103.097002}. 
Similar to the treatment of non-equilibrium quasiparticles for qubit decoherence, e.g. in Ref.~\cite{PhysRevB.86.184514}, we assume that both, the BCS gap and the density of states are not changed, but the distribution function is of a non-equilibrium form.
Although the exact form depends on experimental details most of the non-equilibrium quasiparticles have energies close to the superconducting gap because of scattering with phonons and among each other. 
We therefore assume that the distribution function has a width $\delta$ above the gap, which for a Fermi distribution is determined by temperature, $\delta_{\rm eq}\sim k_BT$, but here it is treated as a parameter. In the following we derive analytical forms for the different rates in the experimental relevant long-time limit $t\gg \delta^{-1}$.


\subsection{Decay}
The relevant energy scale for TLS decay is the TLS energy splitting $E_{\rm TLS}$ as evident from Eq. \eqref{eq:gamma1}. 
The TLS which can be probed by a qubit have energy splittings close to that of the qubit and thus fulfill $E_{\rm TLS}\gg \delta$. In order to evaluate the spectral density in this limit we introduce the normalized quasiparticle density
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="x_{qp}=\frac{1}{\Delta_{\rm BCS}}\int_{\Delta_{\rm bcs}}^{\infty}dE\,\rho(E)f(%
E)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>bcs</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>E</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: For typical TLS energies $\Delta_{\rm BCS}\gg E_{\rm TLS}\gg\delta$ we can apply the 'low-energy' approximation to evaluate the spectral density at the TLS energy \cite{PhysRevB.86.184514, PhysRevB.85.144503}. In this limit all quasiparticle energies in Eq. \eqref{eq:spectralDensity} can be set to $\Delta_{\rm BCS}$. The only exception is the quasiparticle energy in the divergent BCS density of states together with the corresponding distribution function $f(E)$. They enter in the quasiparticle density \eqref{eq:xqp} and the spectral density, describing the decay, reads as
text:
\begin{align}\notag
 S_V(E_{\rm TLS})& = 4N_0^2g_{\alpha\alpha'}^2\Delta_{\rm BCS}(x_{\rm qp,\alpha}+x_{\rm qp,\alpha'})\\
 &\times \rho(E_{\rm TLS}+\Delta_{\rm BCS})
\left(1-\frac{\Delta_{\rm BCS}}{\Delta_{\rm BCS}+E_{\rm TLS}}\cos\varphi\right) \, ,
\end{align}

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle S_{V}(E_{\rm TLS})" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=4N_{0}^{2}g_{\alpha\alpha^{\prime}}^{2}\Delta_{\rm BCS}(x_{\rm qp%
,\alpha}+x_{\rm qp,\alpha^{\prime}})" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>N</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>qp</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>qp</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\times\rho(E_{\rm TLS}+\Delta_{\rm BCS})\left(1-\frac{\Delta_{\rm
BCS%
}}{\Delta_{\rm BCS}+E_{\rm TLS}}\cos\varphi\right)\,," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>TLS</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>φ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: with the Euler constant $\gamma_e$ and the pure dephasing rate
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle h_{R}(t)=\Gamma_{2}^{*}\,t+\pi N_{0}^{2}g_{\alpha\alpha^{\prime}%
}^{2}[f_{\alpha}(\Delta_{\rm BCS})+f_{\alpha^{\prime}}(\Delta_{\rm BCS})]" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>R</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>2</mn><mo>*</mo></msubsup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>N</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\times[1-\cos(\varphi)]\left[\gamma_{e}-1+\log(4\delta\cdot t)%
\right]t" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>×</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>γ</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>δ</mi></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
For scattering quasiparticles we have $\cos\varphi=1$ and the divergent contribution vanishes. Thus, scattering particles induce simple exponential dephasing $\sim e^{-\Gamma_2^*t}$ with rate $\Gamma_2^*$. On the other hand, the dephasing effect of tunneling quasiparticles is dominated by the second term in \eqref{eq:RamseyAna} stemming from the divergent contribution.

The spin echo protocol filters out low energies, but we observe that the relevant energy scales are still much smaller than the width of the quasiparticles. 


Thus the calculation proceeds similar to the calculation for Ramsey dephasing, with the result
prevtext: with the Euler constant $\gamma_e$ and the pure dephasing rate
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma_{2}^{*}=8\pi N_{0}^{2}g_{\alpha\alpha^{\prime}}^{2}\int_{\Delta_{\rm BCS%
}}^{\infty}[f_{\alpha}(E)+f_{\alpha^{\prime}}(E)]dE\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>2</mn><mo>*</mo></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>N</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>BCS</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>α</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>E</mi></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Since the non-divergent part of the spectral density is almost flat for the relevant frequency scales, spin echo does not improve coherence and, similar to white-noise-induced dephasing, the pure dephasing rate $\Gamma_2^*$ is the same for both protocols, spin echo and Ramsey. Thus, for scattering electrons there is no measurable difference between both experimental protocols.aeternus20!0

On the other hand, for tunneling quasiparticles the second term comes into play and dominates dephasing. In this limit the ratio between spin echo and Ramsey is

For scattering quasiparticles we have $\cos\varphi=1$ and the divergent contribution vanishes. Thus, scattering particles induce simple exponential dephasing $\sim e^{-\Gamma_2^*t}$ with rate $\Gamma_2^*$. On the other hand, the dephasing effect of tunneling quasiparticles is dominated by the second term in \eqref{eq:RamseyAna} stemming from the divergent contribution.

The spin echo protocol filters out low energies, but we observe that the relevant energy scales are still much smaller than the width of the quasiparticles. 


Thus the calculation proceeds similar to the calculation for Ramsey dephasing, with the result

\cdot t)\right]t." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>×</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>γ</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
This improvement in dephasing time due to spin echo is typical for noise with divergent spectral density at small energies and could be measured in an experiment.


\section{Conclusion}
We analyzed the decoherence of TLS located in disordered systems in vicinity to superconducting leads, especially inside the amorphous layer of a Josephson junction. We distinguish in our analysis between scattering quasiparticles, that cause decoherence for all the TLS mentioned above, and quasiparticles that tunnel through the junction.
If there exists a phase difference between the superconducting electrodes, the latter exhibit a log-divergent spectral density for low energies leading to increased and time-dependent dephasing rates
while the difference is negligible for the TLS decay. 
We further showed that the spin echo technique reduces the TLS decoherence rate due to tunneling particles, while it has little effect for scattering quasiparticles.
The results obtained for tunneling quasiparticles, arising form a divergent spectral density, apply to single-junction qubits, and they are sensitive to refocusing techniques. This opens possibilities to analyze the quasiparticle-environment of a qubit.

prevtext:
Since the non-divergent part of the spectral density is almost flat for the relevant frequency scales, spin echo does not improve coherence and, similar to white-noise-induced dephasing, the pure dephasing rate $\Gamma_2^*$ is the same for both protocols, spin echo and Ramsey. Thus, for scattering electrons there is no measurable difference between both experimental protocols.aeternus20!0

On the other hand, for tunneling quasiparticles the second term comes into play and dominates dephasing. In this limit the ratio between spin echo and Ramsey is
